Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Relationship of the Spatial/Temporal Variability of Rain to Scaling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists have been studying the non-homogeneity of rainfall for decades. Simply put, raindrops collide, break apart, cluster, and spread out on their way to the ground. This introduces a variety of fall speeds, drop sizes, and instantaneous rainfall intensities that have significant impacts on a wide range of topics from flood forecasting to erosion to communications system availability. This research project will take advantage of a newly developed network of rain sensors to conduct a multitude of studies on rainfall characteristics. The main societal impacts fall under the umbrella of public safety and productivity. Rainfall characteristics are important for weather radars and weather forecast models for flood prediction, and for the prediction of communications drop-outs along land links and satellites. Undergraduate students will participate in the research, allowing for development of the next generation of scientists.

The research team will continue their studies into the spatial and temporal variability of rainfall with an enhanced focus on scaling. The team will perform structural and statistical exploration of rain by collecting and analyzing time series rain observations over a newly configured network that consists of two 2D video disdrometers (2DVD), six 1D optical disdrometers (1DVD), and 21 Laser Precipitation Monitors (LPM). The objectives to be addressed during the work period include: exploring the frequency of the statistical heterogeneity of rain in a wider variety of meteorological conditions, comparing 2DVD observations to those interpolated over a small network of LPMs, characterizing the 1DVD estimates with those of different neighboring instruments, using 2DVD data to detect structures having scales relevant to radar Bragg scatter from precipitation, expanding our understanding of the scaling of DSD and their integrated parameters in statistically homogeneous conditions and in a variety of different meteorological conditions, beginning preliminary observations of the effect of measurements at different heights above ground, and combining 2DVD observations from two instruments for unique simultaneity studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flood prediction and warnings require the accurate translation of rain observations and outputs of numerical models from regional to urban scales. In order to achieve this, we must know how the rainfall rates scales, that is how the rainfall rate say over 1 mile relates to what one might see in their backyard. This is achieved by deriving a mathematical relationship among all of the rainfall rates on all of the different scales. This relation may take many forms, but the most useful is usually in the form of a power-law, that is, the rainfall rate at one scale is related to that at another scale through the ratio of the scales to some exponential power.

            These relations, in turn, are often calculated assuming that the rainfall over a region has certain statistical properties that are the same regardless of where or when they are measured. For simplicity here we refer to these features as WSS (wide-sense statistically stationary). One result of this project is that it is clearly shown why, if WSS applies, the scaling can be considered to have some generality; if not true, however the scaling applies only to that particular set of observations. Consequently, the validity of assuming that a rain event is WSS must be determined for each set of data using techniques developed in our previous NSF-funded research to assure the most accurate warning of the public to a potential flooding danger.

            Other factors, however, have a powerful influence on the derived scaling relations just mentioned. One is the measurement of the rainfall itself. This is done over intervals of time, and in the case of networks of instruments, over areas having some characteristic dimension, D, (like the length of the side of a square network or a diagonal for rectangular or other shapes of networks.) Both the time and any spatial dimension of a network act to filter the data. What does that mean? Just as music has high pitch treble notes and low pitch bass notes, that is a spectrum of pitches, so too rain has high pitch components and low pitch components i.e., a spectrum of different pitches or frequencies. Temporal sampling of rain over an interval is like turning down the treble dial on a radio, while network sampling is like turning down the bass dial on a radio. Just as both change the way the music sounds, so too do the two types of filtering change the frequency spectrum of the rain and, therefore, how the rain scales from the way it would have been without any filtering. This has been studied in this project and is presented as part of a journal article.

            Furthermore, as everyone experiences, rain storms rarely sit in one place but, instead, move. If one were listening to music from a radio on a train that was just sitting still, the music would sound the way it was supposed to. However, it the radio were playing on a passing moving train, it would sound different as the pitch changes. Analogously, when rain passes by, its pitches or spectrum changes too. Moreover, if several radios were playing the same music at different locations on a train, by the time the train passes an observer a different part of the music would be playing. So too rain spectra change in space and in time independently as the storm moves. This affects the observed frequency spectrum of rain and, therefore, the way the rain appears to scale. These too have been in explored in the special case of WSS rain in the same journal article exploring the effects of filtering. The results point out the need to be aware of the motion of the rain during a set of observations.

            While appearing to be rather esoteric, we again remind the reader that these results are important to real world problems of flood forecasting and warnings in order to save lives and to reduce property damage when possible.

            Finally, there are different instruments for measuring the rain. Most people are aware of bucket rain gages where the depth of the collected rain is measured at different times. There are more sophisticated laser-based technologies as well that provide information about the different sizes of raindrops that make up a particular rainfall depth. In this project results two different laser instruments were compared using simultaneous observations. While the net rainfall rates were nearly identical on average, differences were found between the sizes of drops observed. These differences are important to be aware of when computing other quantities, such as how 5G networks might be affected by rain attenuation, using the observed sizes of drops.
